body: I think this is a really great and important addition. Especially if you have already figured out :) I could take an arrayed Tesla instance from AWS to test it out!

multi_gpu_model in the build_model function using the Keras functional api seems to work just fine in talos.Scan when experimental_functional_support=True.

I got a box with 2 cards and both light up when running, so I thought talos already supported this feature.  Is there some other aspect on this that I am totally missing?

@Manofdesign It is possible that it does work just fine since it is basically just a line of code which you can add within the Keras model. I hadn't investigated it at all when I posted the issue, but since you bring it up it is nice to know and should make testing it easier! I just haven't gotten around to anything here since I'm slammed with work right now.

I know if they're Nvidia cards you can do something like `nvidia-smi` to be sure that you're actually using them if you want to double check.

@x94carbone thanks for clarifying.  It definitely works.  I monitor gpu load, gpu memory usage, temp and fan speed on both cards and all measures indicate both are in use.  Multi GPU support is the main feature which lead me to talos.  

I was using GridSearch prior, but it seemed multi-gpu on gridsearch failed for me.  I suspect the memory leak issue.  I saw the git version of talos had the method to reset the session between model builds to clear GPU memory.  That worked great in talos.  When I have it sent to false I can cause a memory leak error from doing enough runs in talos.  When I set it to true, talos clears the memory each run.  Confirmed by setting allow growth in tensorflow session to true and the memory clears and grows to needed amount before each run starts on both GPUs.

@Manofdesign the "allow growth" feature that you mention, is it this one:

```
gpu_options = tf.GPUOptions(per_process_gpu_memory_fraction=0.333)
sess = tf.Session(config=tf.ConfigProto(gpu_options=gpu_options))
```
This seems like something we need to add as an option for the user directly from Scan(). I will test next few days and add it.

Would this do it: 

```
import tensorflow as tf
from keras.backend.tensorflow_backend import set_session


def max_gpu_memory(fraction):

    '''Sets the max used memory as a fraction for tensorflow
    backend

    fraction :: a float value (e.g. 0.5 means 4gb out of 8gb)

    '''

    config = tf.ConfigProto()
    config.gpu_options.per_process_gpu_memory_fraction = fraction
    set_session(tf.Session(config=config))
```

...and we call this in the beginning of the experiment, or if clear_tf_session is set to True, then we do it for every permutation of the experiment? 

I'm creating tf_config.py under /utils where similar things would go in the future. So this would be imported as:

`from talos.utils.tf_config import max_gpu_memory`

@mikkokotila Here is the syntax that I used.  This assumes import keras.backend as K called out earlier.  
```
gpu_options = K.tf.GPUOptions(allow_growth=True)
K.set_session(K.tf.Session(config=tf.ConfigProto(gpu_options=gpu_options)))

h = talos.Scan(x=x_train, y=y_train,
               x_val=x_val, y_val=y_val,
               shuffle=False,
               params=p,
               dataset_name='Simple_MLP_EmbedFalse_featscaleneg',
               experiment_no='2',
               model=create_model,
               grid_downsample=.01,
               last_epoch_value=True,
               experimental_functional_support=True, 
               clear_tf_session=True #very important to prevent memory leak and scan failing
               )
```


To include the fixed percentage

`gpu_options = K.tf.GPUOptions(allow_growth=True, per_process_gpu_memory_fraction=0.5)`

As long as clear_tf_session=True is set, it clears the memory on each permutation but remembers the session settings when it starts the next, so I don't think it needs to be inside the permutation loop.

This brings another thought.  The nature of my current experiment only utilizes < 50% on both cards.  GridSearch has an n_Jobs option where you can set the total number of parallel permutations to run at the same time.  I hate seeing idle compute capacity sitting there and want to squeeze every drop out possible.  Any way to config talos to run parallel permutations.  In that case I think there would need to be more than one session set for each parallel permutation to run in.

I have no idea if this is even possible.  I can do an initial test by setting the per_process_gpu_memory_fraction=0.5 and running two terminal sessions at once to see what happens.  My hope is that both will be running and GPUs will be near 100% usage.

Confirmed.  I can run 2 separate talos.scan sessions with

```
gpu_options = K.tf.GPUOptions(allow_growth=True, per_process_gpu_memory_fraction=0.5)
K.set_session(K.tf.Session(config=tf.ConfigProto(gpu_options=gpu_options)))
```

and both run in parallel nearly utilizing full GPU capacity.  

It would be awesome if talos.Scan had an N_parallel_jobs option where talos would enable multiple sessions as called out and would feed permutations to the session instance that is ready next.
Thanks @Manofdesign and I agree, this is something we need to take seriously. Would this be something you are comfortable contributing with?

@Manofdesign @x94carbone 

As I understand this will be probably the most important think to get right in the roadmap, I'll take a step back and try to dissect. 

It seems that here we are talking now about bigger picture of resources use. First, we have two kinds of systems:

- CPU based
- GPU based 

This is quite important, as for some prediction tasks (e.g. batch_size tends to be small) even a low-end CPU can be an order of magnitude faster than high-end GPU based system. 

Then we have three kinds of distributions: 

- a single resource machine (e.g. a single machine with a single GPU)
- a multi resource machine (e.g. a single machine with many GPUs) 
- multi-machine, single-resources (e.g. many machines, each with single GPU) 
- multi-machine, multi-resource (e.g. many machines, each with many GPUs) 

I'm not sure if multi-CPU utilization is as effective out-of-the-box as CPU core utilization is with Keras/TensorFlow, or is it more like multi-GPU case. 

In terms of experiments, we have several scenarios: 

- a single experiment run as a single job 
- a single experiment run as multiple jobs
- multiple experiments run as a single job 
- multiple experiments run as multiple jobs

I appreciate the fact that multiple experiments run as a single job might not be relevant, but I'm including it for the sake of ontological completeness regarding this topic. 

Basically we are left with 2x4x3=12 relevant cases to figure out and make sure that we cover each in a meaningful way. I think the most complex will be "distributed" scenario where we have multiple machines with multiple GPUs. 

The other interesting thing here might be (at least for very long runs) to have a switch for automatically choosing a given system if CPU, GPU (or TPU) should be used. For example, I have a case where on Google colab it takes 10s per permutation for CPU, 70s/p with GPU and 40s per permutation with TPU. So it would be very easy for the system to auto-optimize and pick CPU for the experiment without the user having to worry about it.

Thoughts?
